titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Exiles Film Project records
titlestmt.author: compiled by Diane Kaplan, Christine Weideman, and Robert Bartels

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 16, 2019 at 07:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The records consist of interviews, interview transcripts, editing and production records, and film footage created during the making of the film, The Exiles . The film, written by Richard Kaplan and Lou Potter, and produced by Richard Kaplan Productions, was released in 1989. Its focus is the European artists, scholars, and intellectuals, mostly Jewish, who escaped totalitarianism and emigrated to America before and during World War II. The film traces their lives in Europe, their escapes, and their impact on American cultural and intellectual life.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The following interviewees have transferred copyright to their interviews to the Yale University Library: Hans Bethe; Felicia Deyrup; Ernst Dichter; Alfred Eisenstaedt; Claire Ehrmann; Felix Gilbert; Mary Jayne Gold; Hannah H. Gray; Dolly Haas; Albert Hirschman; H. Stuart Hughes; Hans Jonas; Erich Leinsdorf; Ralph Lerner; Claude Levi-Strauss; Adolph Lowe; Leo Lowenthal; Golo Mann; Nuria Shoenberg Nona; James Redfield; Wolfgang Roth; Mario Salvadori; Peter Selz; Hans Speier; Lynne Lehrmann Weiner; Helen Wolff; Christiane Zimmer. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Exiles Film Project Records (MS 1734). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Exiles, a film written by Richard Kaplan and Lou Potter, and produced by Richard Kaplan Productions, was released in 1989 and shown on WNET (public television) in New York City. Its focus is the European artists, scholars, and intellectuals, mostly Jewish, who escaped totalitarianism and emigrated to America before and during World War II. The film traces their lives in Europe, their escapes, and their impact on American cultural and intellectual life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The records consist of interviews, interview transcripts, editing and production records, and film footage created during the making of the film, The Exiles . Interview subjects come from a variety of fields including: anthropology (Claude Levi-Strauss); art (Josef Albers, Robert Motherwell); chemistry (Herman Mark); criticism (Frederic Morton); economics (Albert Hirschman, Franco Modigliani); engineering (Mario Salvadori); film and theatre (Dolly Haas, Henry Koster, Erwin Piscator, Rod Steiger, Billy Wilder); history (Felix Gilbert, Hanna Grey, Robert Heilbroner, H. Stuart Hughes, Golo Mann, Peter Selz); law (Henry Ehrmann); music (Kurt Adler, Erich Leinsdorf); philosophy (Hans Jonas); photography (Alfred Eisenstaedt); physics (Hans Bethe, Edward Teller); poetry (Hans Sahl); political science (Erich Hula, Konrad Kellen); psychiatry (Bruno Bettelheim); psychology (Ernest Dichter, Marie Jahoda); publishing (Helen Wolff); sociology (Adolph Lowe, Leo LÃ¶wenthal, Hans Speier); and theology (Wolfgang Roth).

Original (creator assigned) media numbers have been retained: Audio cassettes are numbered 1-118; Betacams are denoted B (or R) 5000-5053; U-matic tapes are denoted U1-U7; VHS tapes are numbered 1-30, or by an identifier from a different format to indicate a VHS copy. Some media have multiple identifiers, to indicate the same interview subject across different formats. Production records contain further documentation on identifiers and interview copies across multiple formats.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The material is arranged into four groupings: interview transcripts, interviews, kine sync film reels, and production material.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Original multi-channel audio recording. The interviewee alone on the left channel and the interviewer and interviewee are both present on the right channel. At 11:23 into the recording, the microphone on the left channel is moved, and it produces a very loud static, noise and hiss, which makes the entire recording unlistenable until 15:29. In the digital preservation master recording, the left audio channel has been removed during this period in order to make it listenable.
